title: Enabling 3D Imaging of Operating Batteries
content: Over the past decade, an explosion of in situ and operando synchrotron-based X-ray studies have provided unprecedented insight into Li-ion batteries and other electrochemical energy storage devices [1-3]. In situ characterization, meaning done without disassembling a system to study its components, and operando characterization, meaning studying the system during normal operating conditions, provide unprecedented insight into complex, dynamic system such as the Li-ion battery. The gained understanding spans the fundamental structureâ€“property relationship of novel energy storage materials and their interfaces as they evolve [4] to issues directly relevant to current commercial battery technologies such as enabling extreme fast charging by avoiding Li metal plating [5] and protecting the layered oxide cathode while expanding the operational voltage window to increase energy capacity [6]. This explosion of X-ray characterization is in part due to the recognition that X-rays, particularly hard X-rays (>5 keV), can penetrate through the standard, single-layer pouch cell battery geometry (Figure 1a), avoiding the need for specialized in situ cells with X-ray transparent windows or modified coin cells (Figure 1b). Specialized in situ cell designs require compromises in electrochemistry performance for the sake of characterization which can result in misleading conclusions. With standard pouch cell batteries, no compromises are needed to accommodate the operando measurements allowing truly realistic electrochemical systems to be characterized. At Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Lightsource (SSRL), this advantage has been realized in how we routinely collect operando X-ray diffraction, absorption spectroscopy, and microscopy.
